Moreover, the sÅ«tras say there are three kinds of karma: wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate. What are their characteristics?
Verse:

Treatise:

Also, the scriptures say that action is of three kinds: meritorious, nonmeritorious, and neither. What are their characteristics?
A verse says:ğŸ”½Meritorious, nonmeritorious, and unmoving. Good actions in the realm of desire are called meritorious.
Bad actions are called nonmeritorious. Good actions in the upper realms are called unmoving.
They are so called because their retribution is unmoving in the place where the action was done.
The treatise says that good actions in the realm of desire are called meritorious because they are opposed to nonmeritorious actions and attract pleasant results.
Bad actions are called nonmeritorious because they attract unpleasant results and are opposed to meritorious actions.
Good actions in the two upper realms are called unmoving.

Did not the World Honored One say that the first three trance states are all called moving, because the holy teachings say that they are moved by the searching, coarse and fine, joy, pleasure, and sensation?
Because the first three trance states have the calamity of searching, coarse and fine, etc., they are called moving.
Unmoving is so called because the scriptures say that it is able to attract unmoving retribution.
How can a moving samÄdhi attract a retribution that is unmoving?

Even though there is agitation and movement in this samÄdhi, the retribution of action is not like that of the realm of desire, which is agitated and moving, and for that reason it is called unmoving.

This means that in the realm of desire, action that should be requited in other destinies and places may be requited in other destinies and places because of the power of other conditions. This is because there are actions that can attract external and internal wealth, status, physical form, size, color, strength, happiness, etc., and action that should be requited in the heavens, etc., may be requited in the human realm, etc., because it is attracted and transformed by the power of other conditions.

Action in other stages and places in the realm of form and the formless realm cannot be transformed to be requited in other stages and places, because the place of requital of action and its results cannot be changed, and because the stages of samÄdhi are not agitated.
It is on the basis of this that the name unmoving is established.

You should know that in this context, the action of non-merit is created out of delusion regarding the connection between cause and effect. Because the action of non-merit is purely defiled, it must be based on the ignorance that is the characteristic of coarseness and continuity.
Because of this ignorance, one is unable to understand and believe in the connection between cause and effect. Therefore, one gives rise to various non-meritorious actions.
Because of delusion regarding the true meaning, one creates meritorious and immovable karma.
The true meaning refers to the Four Noble Truths.

If one is deluded about them, ordinary beings may still give rise to wholesome thoughts in the midst of ignorance. Due to the power of this, they are unable to truly understand that the nature of the three realms is all suffering, and give rise to meritorious and immovable karma as the cause for future existence.

Those who have already seen the truth do not have this. By the power of past actions, when gradually becoming free from defilements, they are reborn in the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm in order.

Others say that even the lower stages have it, because the ripening is experienced in the middle.
Also, it is admitted that these three kinds of actions do not necessarily mature in a fixed order.
There are five kinds of action that is favorable to feeling: by its very nature, associated with feeling,
as object, as retribution, and as actual dharmas.
The treatise says that

all good actions from the realm of desire up to the third trance state are called action that is favorable to the feeling of pleasure, because all feelings of pleasure are only found up to the third trance state.
All bad actions are called action that is favorable to the feeling of suffering.

Good action in the fourth trance state and in the formless realms is called action that is favorable to the feeling that is neither pleasant nor unpleasant, because above that there is no feeling of pleasure or suffering.
You must understand that these actions not only produce feelings as results but also produce the requisites of those feelings.
Feeling and its requisites are called feeling here, and the name feeling is given in general to what is transformed into desire.
Is it admitted that there are actions that are favorable to neither feeling in the lower stages or not?
Other masters say:
In the lower stages there is also karma that is neither, but since there is neither pleasure nor pain in the intermediate state of trance, there would be no karma.

Isnâ€™t it true that the intermediate trance state and the first trance state are bound by the same bond? Therefore the karma of the intermediate trance state produces the faculty of pleasure in the first trance state.
This is not so, because it contradicts the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma.

Is there any karma that produces a pleasant feeling as its retribution, but not a pleasant body?

Yes, namely good karma without vitarka.
Since the karma of the intermediate trance state is without vitarka, if it produces the faculty of pleasure as its retribution, it would be good karma without vitarka.
If it produces both a pleasant feeling and a pleasant body as retribution, it would contradict the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma.
However, this karma produces only a pleasant feeling, just as bad karma produces only a pleasant body.
Even if it is admitted that it produces both, there is no contradiction with the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma.

The ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma should say that it is good karma without consideration, or it should say that not all karma produces feeling as retribution, and therefore it should produce form and dharmas not directly associated with mind.
However, among all actions without investigation, there are actions that can only produce results as mental feelings. Speaking in terms of just those, there is no error.
Therefore, the action of the intermediate concentration produces retribution, but it is not evidence that the lower stages have actions that are neither.
If that is so, there is further evidence here, namely, the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:
Are there three actions whose retributions are neither prior nor subsequent?
It is said:
Yes, they are: actions that accord with pleasant feeling, form;
actions that accord with painful feeling, mind and mental factors;
actions that accord with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, factors not directly associated with mind, and so on, in detail.
By this evidence, it is known that the lower stages also have actions that are neither.
Apart from the desire realm, there are these three actions, because they mature simultaneously.
This is also not evidence, because in the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra, the actions of the three realms are said to be like the three feelings.

However, it is not the case that the results of actions not bound to the three realms can be experienced simultaneously. This is also so for the three realms. The Abhidharma treatise states that the results of actions of the three realms mature simultaneously in order to test whether one understands the tenets of the Abhidharma or not. Alternatively, it speaks of the experience of the dominant result as the experience of the retribution result. Form and formless realm volition nourishes the retribution of the lower realms, causing it to last a long time, and for this reason it is said that the results of actions of the three realms mature simultaneously.

The text can also be interpreted in the same way as the statement that actions are in conformity with the three feelings. Therefore the evidence you have adduced is not conclusive. Why do you insist on investigating what they believe?
We see that what they believe contradicts the PÃµxing lun, which says:
What is action that is in conformity with pleasant feeling?
It is good action bound to the realm of desire up to the third trance state.
There is no contradiction with that treatise, because it does not say that it is only in conformity with pleasant feeling.

Even though there is action in the lower stages that is in conformity with neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling, it is not mentioned in the text because it is slight. You cannot use this to say that
in the upper stages there is also action in conformity with unpleasant and pleasant feeling.
because one is born there only after being free from the defilements of happiness and suffering.

Consequently, only the heaven of vast fruit and above, up to the non-conscious heaven, have karma that is conducive to the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant, and the lower stages are not mentioned, because there is no feeling that is contrary to the feeling of neither suffering nor happiness above, and because there is a feeling that is contrary to it below.

Because it is possible that retribution as neither suffering nor happiness exists in the lower stages, it cannot be definitely determined, as in the case of the three realms of existence, that this text does not have both feelings of suffering and happiness.
Is this karma good or bad?

it is good but inferior.

Also, it cannot be specifically indicated but can be generally said to beğŸ”½among the good karmas, there is one class that is able to induce the feeling of happiness and the requisites of the feeling of happiness, and there is another class that is able to induce neither of the two. You must understand that this karma that benefits the feeling of happiness is called conducive to the feeling of happiness, just as the place where a horse is led.
Or, moreover, this karma is able to feel happiness and is called conducive to the feeling of happiness, just as a bath powder that is conducive to happiness.
It should be understood that the same is true of the other two kinds of karma.
Does karma that produces pleasant feeling only produce pleasant feeling as its retribution?
All that produces pleasant feeling as retribution is karma that produces pleasant feeling.
There is karma that produces pleasant feeling, but it cannot produce pleasant feeling as retribution, namely, if it produces form or the dharmas not directly associated with mind.
It should be understood that the same is true of the other two kinds of feeling.
This karma is not only retribution for feeling. How is it that it is generally called karma that produces feeling?
Because the retribution produced by this karma is similar to feeling and is called feeling.
Why is this?
Because it benefits, injures, and is indifferent to the body, just as feeling does.
This is established in the same way that water, fire, etc., benefit, injure, and are indifferent to the branches of a tree, etc.

Moreover, karma that produces feeling is of five kinds: 1) that which produces feeling by nature, i.e., the substance of the feeling, as a scripture says,ğŸ”½â€œThe six feelings, i.e., feelings born of contact through the coming together of eye, form, and visual consciousness, etc.â€
When experiencing pleasant feeling, one accurately knows that one is experiencing pleasant feeling, and so on in detail.
Second, feeling associated with objects, which means all contacts, as a sutra says:
Contact that accords with pleasant feeling, and so on in detail.
Third, feeling that takes objects as its objects, which means all objects, as a sutra says:
When the eye sees forms, one only experiences the forms and does not experience craving for forms, and so on in detail.
Because forms and so on are the objects of feeling.
Fourth, feeling that is the ripening of karma, which means karma that produces ripening, as a sutra says:
Karma that accords with pleasant feeling, and so on in detail.
Fifth, feeling that is present, which means presently operating feeling, as a sutra says:
When experiencing pleasant feeling, two feelings cease, and so on in detail.

When this pleasant feeling is present, no other feeling can experience this pleasant feeling. It is only said that the pleasant feeling itself, being present, experiences itself. This is because there are many kinds of feelings that are experienced.
Although the karmic maturation of action is not all feeling, it can be generally established as action that is conducive to feeling.

This means that form and the factors not directly associated with mind, which are experienced as a result of the cause of good action, can be the objects that give rise to pleasant feeling, because they are what pleasant feeling experiences.

Because the pleasant karmic maturation is conducive to pleasant feeling, it is also called pleasant feeling. Therefore, although the results that are attracted by this good action are not pleasant feeling, because they are conducive to pleasant feeling, the action that attracts them is called action that is conducive to pleasant feeling.
The same principle applies to action that is conducive to suffering and to neither.
What are the characteristics of these three kinds of action that are definite and those that are indefinite?
The verse says:
These have definite and indefinite results. The definite ones are three: conducive to present experience, etc.
Or it is said that action is fivefold. Other masters say that there are four alternatives.
The treatise states:ğŸ”½

The Treatise says that the above-mentioned karma that produces pleasant feeling, etc., should be known as having definite and indefinite differences. It is called indefinite because the retribution is not definite.

This means that karma that produces pleasant feeling is not necessarily matured, but if it is matured, it must produce pleasant retribution. The explanation is the same for the other two kinds of karma.
There are three kinds of definite karma:
1. Karma whose retribution is experienced in the present life, 2. Karma whose retribution is experienced in the next life, and 3. Karma whose retribution is experienced in a later period.
These three kinds of definite karma definitely produce retribution. Together with the above indefinite karma, they make four kinds in all.

Some people want to make the indefinite karma into two kinds, namely, karma whose retribution is definite and karma whose retribution is indefinite. Together with the above three kinds of definite karma, they make five kinds in all.
What is the nature of karma whose retribution is experienced in the present life?
It is that which is created and increased in this life and whose retribution is experienced only in this life and not elsewhere.

The words â€œin this lifeâ€ indicate a class of beings. In order to illustrate the path of action of the fundamental karma, the words â€œcreated and increasedâ€ are used. In order to illustrate the subsequent action, the words â€œincreasedâ€ are used.

However, some say that in the human realm, one creates and increases [karma], and then in this human life, one experiences the ripening of the other body [in the form realm]. This is also called karma that ripens in the present life.
To refute this view, it is further said that it is not the other [body].

This then shows that for one who dies and is reborn, it can be said that it is only this [human body] and not the other [form realm body]. By this, it makes it extremely clear and cuts off all doubts that the time period of the karma is not destroyed.
How does this statement it is not the other make one definitely know that it is not the other body's experience?
This is because the statement it is not the other can be interpreted as negating the human realm and not negating the other body.
This interpretation is unreasonable, because the previous statement only this has already established the meaning of negating the non-human realm.
That is to say, since the previous statement has already said only this life, it has already definitely shown that it is not the non-human realm.
However, the subsequent statement it is not the other clearly negates the other body. If it were otherwise, what would be the point of repeating it?
Therefore, this action is called action that produces results in the present life, because the present life means the present body.
What is the nature of action that produces results in the next life?
It means that action done in this life produces results in the next life.
The word life means the meaning of birth. Action done in this life produces results in the next life without interruption, so it is called the next life.
This is the meaning of the next life. Action that produces results in the next life is called action that produces results in the next life.
What is the nature of action that produces results in subsequent lives?
It means that action done in this life produces results in the next life without interruption.
The word subsequent means the subsequent homogeneous group without interruption after birth. The word life shows that it is experienced in many lives in sequence.
The meaning of this statement is to show that action that produces results in subsequent lives definitely produces results in one life in sequence.
In order to avoid the fault of too many words, the same name is established in general for many actions.
What is called action that produces results in indefinite lives?

The BhagavÄn saw that some karma, whether due to morality, right aspiration, pure conduct, meditative concentration, or the power of wisdom, either has no result, or causes a slight result, or causes a change in status. He said that all of this is called indeterminate karma. In order to transform this karma, one should cultivate pure conduct.
This karma is the most common among sentient beings.
However, the sÅ«tra says:
There is karma that should be experienced in the present life, but may be transferred to be experienced in hell. This is not discussing karma that should be experienced in the present life.

It means there is karma that should be experienced in an indeterminate way. If one diligently cultivates morality, concentration, and wisdom, then the karma one creates should be experienced in the human realm. Due to not diligently cultivating morality, concentration, and wisdom, one falls into hell by relying on this karma.
The sÅ«tra also says:

Or, there are actions that should be experienced in hell, but are sometimes experienced in the human realm. This also does not clarify the fixed time of karma, but only speaks of its indefiniteness. The interpretation of the meaning is the same as before.

Or, it is explained that the previous sÅ«tra means that there are actions that are created but not increased. If one leaves them as they are, they should be experienced in the present life. If one later creates actions that lead to hell, they assist and increase them, causing one to experience them in hell.
Therefore, a sÅ«tra says:

There are actions that should be experienced in the human realm in the present life. Due to later creating actions that lead to hell and causing them to increase, they cause one to experience them in hell instead.
Therefore, we know that it refers to indeterminate karma.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:

Karma to be experienced in the present life, etc., can also be experienced in other lives. However, according to the initial stage of ripening, it is called karma to be experienced in the present life, etc. It does not only attract that much result as its name indicates.

That is, they mean that if the various karmas that are created can immediately become causes and give results that are their ripenings, they are called karmas whose results are experienced in the present life.ğŸ”½If they become causes and give results that are their ripenings in the next life, they are called karmas whose results are experienced in the next life.
If they give their ripenings in the third life or later, they are called karmas whose results are experienced in subsequent lives.
Why do they make this interpretation?
They fear that the ripening of strong karma would be small.
This interpretation is not good.
Why?
Because it is impossible for the ripening of a karma to arise again after it has already arisen and then has been interrupted, just as a sprout does not arise again after it has arisen.

If you say that the later body arises without interruption, then there would be no death and rebirth, because the karma would not be different. Or, if the body is not different, then there would be frequent death and rebirth.
Also, if one karma attracts two or three lives, etc., are the characteristics of the results of this karma different or the same?

If the characteristics are different, then, like the continuity of the results of different actions, they would not be the results of a single action. Or, if the results of a single action have the same characteristics, how can you explain the differences in their characteristics before and after?

If you say that the perfuming of the results of other actions helps to make them different, then there should be differences before and after in a single life. We see that although there are many differences in the results of the perfuming of the results of many actions in a single life, the single life is still called a single life because of the single action that attracts it.
This should be the same, because there is no other reason.

If the characteristics are the same, then there should be only a single life, and the characteristics before and after in a single life should be the same. But we see that there are differences before and after in the process of life.
This should be the same, because the results of a single action are the same.

But you cannot say that a single life is the result of many attracting actions, because the actions that attract it are different. Or, in the state of prior existence, there should be death and birth, or there should be no death and birth.
Also, if many lives are the result of a single action, are they in a single realm of existence or in many realms?

If the intermediate existence and the five destinies are the same, then the error of the previous explanation is incurred, that is, the intermediate existence and the five destinies would be the same life.
Or, in one life there would be repeated birth and death, because the fruit of one action would be undifferentiated.

If the intermediate existence and the five destinies are different, then the various destinies would be distinguished as superior, middling, and inferior, and therefore the same fruit of one action would not be possible, because it is impossible for one instant of action to have superior, middling, and inferior.
Also, in that case, the destinies would be mixed, but the destinies are not mixed, as has been explained previously.

If you claim that in the intermediate existence that is projected by other actions, there is an action that has already produced a fruit in a previous life, and the power of the action to produce a fruit has not yet been exhausted, so that one experiences a different retribution in this life, then even though one action can project many lives, there is a distinction of superior and inferior fruits of death and birth.
This is also unreasonable.
Why?
Because in the intermediate existence projected by other actions, the action that is experienced again is neither projected nor completed.
Is the retribution that is received in another life in dependence on another life a projecting cause or a completing cause?
It is not the case that one receives a projected result in dependence on another life, because the result of that life is projected by another action.
One result should not project and then be projected again. One action should not be useless, and the latter action would be completely useless in that case.

Nor can it be said that there are two projected results in one life, because it would then be possible for a single consciousness to experience the results of many lives, many destinies, and the results of retribution occurring simultaneously.

Nor can it be said that one receives a completed result in dependence on another life, because it would then be possible for a projecting action to obtain a projected result in a previous life, and the remaining projecting power would continue into the present life and transform into a completed result.

That is, there is a type of action whose results are to be received in the next life. Having projected a result in the next life, it now transforms into a completed result in another life projected by another action. In that case, a single action would both project and complete, and there would be the error of confusion between projecting and completing.

Moreover, all actions mutually assist each other, and thus all are completed in terms of both performance and increase. Then it would be absolutely impossible for any action not to receive retribution, and one would never attain nirvÄá¹‡a.

However, this is not accepted by either of the two schools. The fault is especially great for the SautrÄntikas, because in their school, actions that are to be experienced in the present life, etc., are not definite, yet they accept that all actions mutually assist each other, and therefore they should all be completed in terms of both performance and increase.
The World-Honored One said in the scriptures that actions that are both performed and increased are definite.
Those who say that all actions are indefinite should be known as outsiders to the Buddhaâ€™s teachings.

Moreover, on what principle do they rely in this matter to accept that in the production of other actions, the remaining actions that have already produced results in a previous life can assist in completion and cause them to last long?
They do not accept that in a previous life, those that have already been produced by oneself can be the cause of completion and cause them to continue.

Also, if there is karma that is to be experienced in a heaven, and after death in a heaven one is born in hell, how can karma to be experienced in a heaven in a future life cause one to experience a pleasant result in hell? And how can one, after death in hell, be born in a heaven?
The same is true if we reverse the order of heaven and hell.

Karma to be experienced in a heaven in a future life cannot cause one to experience its result in AvÄ«ci Hell, nor can karma to be experienced in AvÄ«ci Hell cause one to experience its result in a heaven.
If you say that this karma can only cause one to experience its result again in a heaven, after one has transcended the other destinies, we have already refuted this.
What was the refutation?
We said that it is not reasonable for a result to be produced again after having already been produced, because the result is like a sprout.
Although they offer a reason to prove their interpretation, saying that strong karma should not have a small result,
this is not a proof.
Why is it not a proof?
Because the strength of karma is not determined by the amount of the result.
Karma to be experienced in the present life is called strong because it is able to quickly obtain a result.

If many volitions arise in one thing, with differences in superiority and inferiority before and after, it can induce results of retribution in the present, next, and later lives. Saying it attracts many results is also not wrong.

Moreover, if it is held that karma must induce many results in order to be called strong, then the karma that induces the result of retribution of a wheel-turning king, compared to the karma that induces the karma of a Buddha, should be said to be strong, because it induces many results.
If the karma that induces the karma of a Buddha is called strong because it is wonderful, then there are many kinds of strong karma, because the principle of strong karma has many categories.
That is to say, there is karma whose result is near and is called strong, or whose result is many, or whose result is wonderful.
However, karma to be experienced in the present life is called strong because its result is near. How can the name strong be used to prove that it induces many results?

Therefore, the Abhidharma masters say that among all karmas, the three of those to be experienced in the present life, etc., each separately produces results, and the results of karma are not mixed. This is superior in principle.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that karma has four statements:

First, there is karma whose time period is definite but whose retribution is indefinite, referring to the three types of karma that are conducive to the present life, etc., which are not definitely able to obtain retribution.
Second, there is karma whose retribution is definite but whose time period is indefinite, referring to indeterminate karma that is definitely able to obtain retribution.
Third, there is karma whose two aspects are both definite, referring to karma that is conducive to the present life, etc., which is definitely able to obtain retribution.
Fourth, there is karma whose two aspects are both indefinite, referring to indeterminate karma that is not definitely able to obtain retribution.
They say that all karma in total becomes eight types, namely, that which is conducive to the present life and so on, which each have two types, definite and indefinite.
Among the distinctions of karma that have been explained, a verse says:
Four kinds of good karma can be performed together, but only three attract rebirth in the same class.

In all realms, four kinds are performed, but in hell, good karma excludes that which is conducive to the present life.ğŸ”½Firmly, in the stage of separation from desire, ordinary beings do not perform karma that produces rebirth.
The sages do not perform karma that produces rebirth or a later life, and also not when falling away from the desire realm or the peak of existence.
The treatise says:

The SÅ«tra says that there are four kinds of karma: that which is to be experienced in the present life, that which is to be experienced after rebirth, that which is to be experienced in some subsequent time, and that which is not to be experienced. The first three kinds are definite, and the fourth is indefinite. The first three are further divided into three kinds each, and the fourth is not divided. This is the correct explanation.
There is no karma whose time of retribution is indefinite and whose nature is definite. The time is definite only when the nature is definite.
Apart from the nature, there is no time. How can the time be definite when the nature is indefinite?
Here, the time is established according to the definite nature of the karma that is to be experienced.

If there is karma whose time is definite, that is, whose retribution must occur at a certain time and not at another, and which is never not experienced, then the time is definite but the nature is indefinite.
This is also definite with regard to the nature. The meaning is similar.
What is similar?

That is, just as time is determined when there is existence, or when it is named without reason, time is determined in the same way. Similarly, when there is existence, or when it is named without reason, the retribution should be determined. Alternatively, it should be admitted that both are undetermined.
Therefore, if an action is determined in time, its retribution should also be definite.
If the retribution is called indefinite, then the time should also be indefinite.

For this reason, there definitely are not eight kinds of action. Those that have an indefinite meaning among the various actions should be collectively established as one kind that conforms to indefinite retribution.
Why is this?
Because the meanings are similar.

That is, just as definite retribution and indefinite time are admitted to be that which conforms to indefinite retribution because the time is indefinite, in the same way, definite time and indefinite retribution should be admitted to be that which conforms to indefinite retribution because the retribution is indefinite.
Therefore, the establishment of eight kinds of action by the proponents of examples is extremely confused.

Also, the proponents of examples say that all actions, even up to the uninterrupted [paths], can all be turned. If the uninterrupted path cannot be turned, then there would be no one able to transcend the first concentration.

Now, observing their statement, there is such an intention. If it is said that among the various actions, there is a small amount that cannot be turned, then the action of the summit of existence will definitely precede it, because among the various actions, the action of the summit of existence is the most subtle, the basis of all birth and death, and has the power to attract vast results and retribution. Sentient beings who have been transmigrating in birth and death since beginningless time have never been able to transcend it.
If there is someone able to turn this kind of action, then how could the uninterrupted path not be able to be turned?
